The Space Vacuum.

The reason for this is to share with you an idea of ​​a system to clean the atmosphere, the ozone layer of pollution generated by man. With the idea that I propose, it will be possible to clean the atmosphere to a large extent, and thus avoid global warming and all its consequences.

My project is called "The Space Vacuum"

it consists of a platform placed in orbit, similar to a space station, which has a gigantic tube so to speak that connects outer space and the atmosphere.
The space vacuum takes advantage of the "suction force of the space vacuum", Things are "pushed" by pressure, more specifically by the difference in pressure of a gaseous medium between two adjacent areas. Suppose a spaceship bursts the hatch and everything goes flying. In reality, the vacuum did not pull anything, but everything loose was pushed from the area of ​​higher pressure to the area of ​​lower pressure.

The same effect is achieved if we connect the atmosphere to outer space by means of a gigantic tube, and thus suck out the pollution, all the greenhouse gases along with the pollution would be expelled out of the earth into space, where they do not harm the Earth. ozone layer. By connecting outer space with the earth's atmosphere a bridge would be created, this bridge is the gigantic tube that allows the expulsion of greenhouse gases.

The space vacuum would have a system of chambers and valves that open and close to control what is ejected into space. You understand me? The tube has a mechanism that opens and closes as needed, thus controlling the suction, thus preventing all the oxygen in the atmosphere from escaping.

Harnessing the space vacuum cleaner.

- All the garbage on the planet could be expelled into space.

- All radioactive material could be expelled from nuclear power plants.

- In the event of a third world war, a "nuclear winter" could be avoided since the space vacuum cleaner would clean all the clouds of gases, dust and other contaminants produced by nuclear explosions.

- Capsules can be created to send humans to space, tools and equipment, something like an elevator to space, thus being totally carbon neutral, zero pollutant.

- Could be used by Elon Musk to capture Co2 and turn it into fuel

The space vacuum cleaner could save man from extinction and life in general on planet Earth.

I can share the plans and photos of my idea . write me.

I am Hugo Rodríguez from Costa Rica
Thank you very much!
Cheers, Pura Vida!!

At this point in time going to Mars is totally pointless. Even our return to the Moon is just utter nonsense.
1. Sending humans to Mars is a garbage idea - humans may not survive the trip and performing basic tasks on Mars may be nearly impossible or highly disruptive for health.
2. On a lifeless planet we have to bring our own food, water, air, medication, medical equipment, transport vehicles, spare parts for everything. Basically, if a life-threatening accident happens with a crew member there has to be a fully equipped and powered operating room with a full team of doctors and medical equipment to treat the patient 34 million miles away from the nearest hospital.
3. If for some reason the return ship can't pick up the humans this will mean certain death for all of them with no resources, no supplies and probably equipment that keeps breaking due to the conditions on the planet.
So far no interviewer has ever asked Musk about WHY we are going to Mars and the only reason the Americans set foot on the Moon was to beat the Russians to it. We have not mined the moon, sustaining moon bases is too expensive and pointless, has no strategic bonuses etc.
If we can figure out why we are going to Mars and not just how, maybe we can build the right robots to do our job there instead of driving humans to their almost certain slow death on a lifeless planet. Even if Mars was made out of 100% pure gold, mining it from 34 million miles away using human labor would be much more expensive than mining it on Earth.

Elon mentioned a potential 10,000 times reduction in cost per ton to Mars; $1,000,000,000 (One Billion) per ton to send current rovers, down to an aspirational $100,000 per ton with some future Starship design. With Starship aiming to send 100 tons to the surface of Mars, this means Each starship launch to Mars would have a cost of $10,000,000 (Ten Million).

This is obviously assuming reusability, which includes flying Starship from Mars back to Earth. Based on delta-v requirements, it will be necessary to refuel Starship on Mars for the return flight, and I can only assume the cost of refueling out of Martian in-situ propellant has not been factored into this 10 million dollar price tag.

The 10 million dollar cost also seems to be just SpaceX's cost of fuel and maintaining the program, with the cost of building the rocket amortized over a large number of uses, but you can't achieve a large number of uses if every use goes to Mars, since it simply takes too long for rapid reuse (2-3 years per round trip). This means, in order to amortize the manufacturing cost over a large number of uses, Starships optimized for Mars landings will need to have the ability to be used in LEO or on the Moon as well after making some launches to Mars to be able to take advantage of a market with a higher launch cadence.

Even if it only costs SpaceX 10 million to fly the mission to Mars, there is an opportunity cost which might increase the price; if that same Starship could service the LEO launch market as well, then does it make sense to accept even a 20 million dollar payment for a trip to Mars (10 million profit) that requires it to be unable to be used for LEO launches for 2-3 years? Surely the profits per Starship serving the LEO launch market will be greater than 5 million dollars a year. Heck, it will probably be more than 5 million dollars of profit per launch, with many launches per year per starship. Therefore, the largest cost of sending a Starship to Mars could be the opportunity cost of preventing that rocket from servicing the LEO launch market for 2-3 years.

Of course, with such a high launch cadence and the ability to construct Starships quickly there is a good chance that there could be enough Starships to service the LEO market, Lunar market, and Martian market all at the same time. These markets will surely grow with lower cost access due to Starship, but I suspect Starship production will be able to keep up with this demand. Regardless, unless there is some other form of revenue stream from the Mars base, or SpaceX charges a huge premium on flights to Mars, supplying the demand for launches to Mars will be Starship's least profitable use case.

I doubt this will stop SpaceX or Elon from making Mars optimized Starships though! But I would have loved to see Tim ask Elon about the economics of using Starship for Mars vs LEO.

I don't know if anyone else mentioned it in the thousands of comments so far, but on Apollo, the S-IVB third stage used ullage gas propulsively, though not for full 3-axis control.
After its first burn to get into Earth orbit, the S-IVB's tanks were still mostly full of liquid oxygen and hydrogen intended for the TLI burn to send Apollo to the Moon. The liquid hydrogen continued to boil off and that gas was sent to propulsive vents at the rear of the vehicle. While in Earth orbit, the stack maintained a 'pointy-end-forward' attitude and the rearward-venting hydrogen served to keep the propellants settled to the bottom of their tanks and away from their vents.

comment_text:
I've always wondered if fins (or wings for that matter) have to be so large.
What if you have an array or hundreds or more piezoelectric (if possible based on heating concerns), zirconium-doped wing fence-type (or slightly scaled up) control surfaces covering a mathematically-determined area of the vehicle's skin? There would no longer be a single point of failure. And, each member would experience relatively low wing-loading, as opposed to exposing one-to-four large control surfaces to superheated, hypersonic airflow.
Think of a hypersonic snail, a snail whose velocity is scaled and accelerated up for mass and velocity. In a snail, all of those phenomenally-coordinated, cilia-like members collectively generate useful motion for a macro-scale organism. Why not pick up where nature left off and scale it up to allow the skin of a reenterig spaceship to groove into its desired path?

Was the $100K per ton to Mars the theoretically possible optimal result of Starship technology? Or did Elon actually think that the current design could already be in that ballbark? Even missing that target by a single magnitude would still result to $1M/ton to Mars which would be insanely cheap compared to anything we currently have.

To put things into perspective, you could deliver F-35 to Mars instead of any given country on Earth for only 25% extra cost over the whole aircraft alone. Obviously that jet cannot do anything sensible there but the cost of building high tech stuff would be more than the delivery cost, unlike today.

when you guys were discussing the cost per ton to Mars, he said in order to make colonization viable costwise, the cost to weight ratio would have to improve by roughly 10,000%, and you and the other guy kinda giggled, but Elon. He certainly had no similance of a smile on his face. I just thought of how odd the juxtaposition of your vs his reaction to that statement. I suppose it's a matter of perspective. He's the man responsible for accomplishing that 10,000% cost reduction. I'm also fascinated by watching this man interact with other people conversationally. Yes the Asperger's does have an effect,.but I see it a bit deeper than that. It seems to me, to be a difficult challenge for Elon to basically dumb himself down enough to answer other's questions. Not in an arrogant way at all, more like it takes him time to come up with a response that he thinks you'll be able to understand. You can see it when, for example you ask him a truly relevant technical question. It seems like he's happy that you have more than a layman's comprehension of whatever you guys happen to be talking about, making it easier for him to reply, and he visibly relaxes a little. I don't know how well he knows you, but I can tell that as you guys go on, it gets more and more comfortable for him. I guess he realizes he's not got to dumb it down quite so much. That's just a theory, but another I have is that dude thinks so fast, that he's moved on, and is bored before he gets out the full reply to a sentence lol. Ya know, either/or lol. I will admit that you guys actually used 19 words during your dialogue, that I have a firm grasp on, regarding their meaning, use, and purpose. That makes me pretty smart. Granted, I have to have a net increase of around 10,000% "roughly" in my intelligence level, to bridge the knowledge per minute of conversation before I actually try and participate in this conversation with you guys. Baby steps, some day, you, Elon, myself, full on discussion time, and no drool on my chin!

I continue to think that this type of communication, sharing, and invitation is what sets Elon Musk way apart from the 'other' guys in the business. The 'other' guys invite senators and folks from the military industrial complex because that's where their funding comes from. At Starbase in Boca Chica, just observe the difference in how people talk to you about what they're working on. You feel like you're the CEO and they are giving you a status report. It's very surreal at times but also, in my opinion, why SpaceX emits a completely different vibe than NASA or the other aerospace incumbents. Trust can be a lot higher when you invite a person in to see what you've been up to and what you want to do next. That's something the 'agencies' should remember in the future. In the cases where a company is accepting or spending public funds, providing a full view of your progress should not be up for debate. I think it's actually what helps to keep you honest.

I had thought of his fwd flap optimization. Basically you don't need a hot gas seal on the hinge if they're mounted completely leeward and just stick out into the air stream, with the hinge completely hidden from the air stream. I'm surprised they haven't done it. There are a couple of other options too, e.g. fixed fwd flaps with control surfaces protruding from the flap leeward side, those would require less control authority to adjust too.

I see no reason why a very large parachute(s) could not be deployed at the very beginning of reentry. Parachutes have been used on aircraft in its weight class many times. It could be triggered by a pressure switch so it would be deployed when air resistance would be optimal. A parachute can be manipulated to alter the rate of descent or to change course to some degree. The ship could come down engines first, this would eliminate the need for the dreaded flip maneuver, it would also solve all those pressure problems. Reentry could be extended to about 3-5 hours.
There would be a significant weight reduction, no heat tiles and the lower and upper flaps/fins would no longer be needed. There would be a significant decrease in drag which would reduce the amount of propellant and oxidizer needed. It would also be much safer, if just one of those heat tiles fails the whole ship will be lost.

Ullage gas: If you have separate ullage gas and reaction controll when you vent the ullage gas (in a random way) you have to correct for the thrust accidentally created by the ullage gas dumping. So, there are two savings, not having to do planned course correction and not having to correct for random thrust from ullage dumping.

Watching Elon Musk - as a businessman and private citizen - explain how he plans to create spacecraft capable of taking humans to Mars feels so much like an early Heinlein novel brought to life. Just mind-blowing to see it actually being realized now. I'm 63, and for most of my life I thought I wouldn't live long enough to see this happen; that NASA would continue to dominate space flight and it would stay on it's slow, plodding course, so that the goal of going to Mars would likely occur long after my life expired, if ever. I'm beginning to think I might see it happen after all, and I can't express the depth of joy and hope that provides as I enter my twilight years. With all the madness and evil in the world right now, what Musk is attempting to accomplish is one of the very few things that really makes me want to stick it out and hang on as long as I can.

If we're talking about a potential site for a Mars city, my vote is for the point of lowest elevation in the Hellas impact basin. The atmospheric pressure there is the highest on Mars, is roughly twice the planetary average. This would provide increased radiation shielding for colonists. Also, at certain times in the Martian year the pressure and temperature conditions just reach the triple point of water, allowing liquid water to exist on the surface without evaporating. With some dredging and digging, we could create a basin where water could exist year-round either as liquid or ice.

Elon addresses one of the most important aspects of engineering, and why NASA and other companies have so much trouble getting things done. Do not try and reach perfection before production! Get it doing what you want it to do, THEN start optimizing and perfecting. Then after production begins, keep engineering on continued improvement of the product and how it is manufactured. So many companies see the design process as a finite project to be handed off to production and then forgotten about.

The level of access interested folks have on this project and the time period in which we live being increasingly captive of our progress and accomplishments as a species, is truly special. It's also a huge thanks to Elon for making this such an open and accessible project given the importance, scale (physically, financially, historically), and cutting edge of tech being used, where there isn't too much general restriction in the access given. Obviously we're not onsite touring every bit of new engineering methods and designs developed for this project, but many companies are so paranoid, secretive, and honestly just plain 'ole greedy, that access to roam around with the boss during extended interviews would simply not be a thing. It's also important that Elon genuinely appears to be as talented an engineer as his hand-selected engineering project leads, and is willing to simply have discussions with them to bounce off ideas and debate the positives of a given suggestion. That's so rare to have, and may be one of the features unique to SpaceX which results in their ultimate success when they surpass all competitors by competing and achieving the master prize of Mars; far beyond the ambitions of other private Space companies with actual operations today.

Then the Falcon 9 has already been so prolific, it has reinvigorated the industry and the number of space launches per year to an incredibly quick scale-up, with the projected number only looking to increase in the coming years.

Obviously, there's going to be a bias when asking current living people if this is part of the natural development of our species and its relationship with technology, or if this is a truly special and transformative series of just a few decades where the entire concept of science and technology permanently impact all future lives. One of the primary points, in a series of conclusions laid out where virtually every futurist agrees on (say 99%), is the conclusion that this is a truly rare developmental time period for the species as a whole, and we're lucky to be experiencing it. It's hard to argue against when we've seen the progress over the last 200 years, and then compare it to the projects currently being researched and worked on set to take formation over just the next 20 years (rather than 200), while being a couple orders of magnitude more complex and efficient versus the past 200 years of principle changes.

These captions are unsatisfactory. They're full of mistakes. Uploading bad captions is worse than using Youtube's auto-generated ones, because, with the latter option, you at least know to take them with a grain of salt. When you upload captions, you're implicitly certifying them. You're telling people to trust your captions as the final word on what's being said in the video. And when you upload bad captions, you're betraying that trust. I can't tell you how frustrating this is, especially for those learning English as a second language, who don't yet have the mental machinery in place to resist being misled and confused.

I understand that it's expensive to create quality captions for a 45 minute video. While it would be nice to have handmade captions for every video, I recognise that that isn't realistic. Just leave it to Youtube's auto-generated captions, which have their own issues, but at least don't claim to be more accurate than they are! And if you're going to go to the trouble of creating your own captions, do it right or don't do it at all. But if you're uploading captions (without regard for their quality) in the hope that the Youtube algorithm will look more favorably upon a video that apparently has handmade captions, that certainly is despicable.

People use captions for various reasons. It isn't just the deaf. Because of the windy audio in this video, I imagine more people than usual will look to captions for help understanding. For some, the poor-quality captions will simply be an annoyance. For others, they will be a serious impediment to understanding and literally worse than nothing.

When Musk talked about removing the Forward flaps, it occurred to me that the Mig-105 may not be the only Soviet aircraft to present a bit of inspiration.

The Mig-21i was a testbed for the Tu-144 Supersonic airliner, testing the ogival delta wing. I think Starship may benefit greatly from an ogival delta with a bit of chines to balance center of pressure. And the aft fins already seem to follow that sort of design.

I liked the way Elon and Joe (director, Starship engineering ) interact.
They both seem comfortable with how dynamic the SpaceX design process is. No egos, no superiority, just a nerdy love of making it better to timely priorities.
Joe has no reaction to Elon throwing ideas around, like shifting upper flap mount positions, grid fin numbers, potential COPV removal, he takes it all in his stride,
It's just something that may or may not happen several iterations down the track, or already design work in progress.
I could see a journeyman NASA engineer having trouble adapting to this sort of culture and having trouble not being precious about ideas and being frustrated with the constant buoyant design priorities.
That's what most impressed me in the take away from this video.

Tim, really great video. Love the highly technical discussion, the deep end of the pool.
Couple of suggestions?
1) Audio pick-up on Elon suffered whenever he crossed his arms. I'm trying to understand this, thinking he's got a wireless mic -- somewhere -- and somehow it is affected by his arm positions. Next time (hoping there is a next time) might find a different (better) location to clip the lav mic. Great audio is arguably more important (in this case) than the video.
2) Your questions and obvious deep knowledge of the topic are what helps make this video so good. One thing to alter: shorten-up the questions. 60 Minutes interviewers do two things: short to-the-point questions, and they rarely interrupt the interviewee... even allowing a long pause so allow the interviewee think for a moment and then add more insight to their answers.
3) Engage with some of the YouTube comments. Perhaps you are, but a quick view of these comments doesn't show you having replied. Not every comment (most don't require any follow-up), but some, if for no other reason than to show you're connected to us as well.

As for making the cargo-release mechanism inside Starship, why not have a single hinge-pin on the side that twists the entire cargo-space off sideways? Basically emptying the entire space out form the underside? No obstructions, and the cone is entirely intact, as well as the top part of the booster, maintaining structural stability. The underside could the be sealed and re-sealed with a simple O-ring.

The only disadvantage I could see would be having the line to the header-tank pass through or around the hinge and being able to twist/rotate 180 degrees.

29:31 sort of an off the cuff hidden gem, "you can't cheat if you get cost/ton to orbit". May reflect the thought he's given to scoring functions in artificial intelligence. The correct scoring function is the one for which an A.I. cannot cheat, since if it were to find some cheap trick that massively improved the score, a human operator wouldn't care and would actually think it's fantastic.
30:49 An improvement of 4 orders of magnitude drains the blood from my face. On the bright side, the mental framework makes for fun work. One can look at the current method of mars transport, or the current method that SpaceX proposes, and decompose the method into tasks (orbital injection, orbital cruise, atmospheric entry, parachuting, landing burn, etc.) each with associated cost, then find inefficiencies in tasks or find ways to cut tasks out entirely.
